identificationModule.briefTitle: Impact of a Standardized Alarming System on Treatment Times and Workflow in Stroke Patients With Interhospital Transfer for Thrombectomy
identificationModule.officialTitle: Impact of a Standardized Alarming System on Treatment Times and Workflow in Stroke Patients With Interhospital Transfer for Thrombectomy

descriptionModule.briefSummary:
The aim of this study is to evaluate the impact of a standardized alarming system on treatment times and workflow in stroke patients with interhospital transfer for mechanical thrombectomy (MT). The main questions it aims to answer are:

* Is the implementation of a standardized alarming system associated with shorter transfer and treatment times?
* Is the implementation of a standardized alarming system associated with a better adherence on existing standard operating procedures for interhospital transfer? We will analyze data from our existing thrombectomy registry comparing time periods before and after introduction of the MT alarming system.

keywords: mechanical thrombectomy, telestroke, drip and ship, interhospital transfer, communication

armGroups.label: pre implementation period
armGroups.description: stroke patients transferred within the 6 months before introduction of the alarming system

armGroups.label: implementation period
armGroups.description: stroke patients transferred within the 6 months after introduction of the alarming system

armGroups.label: post implementation period
armGroups.description: stroke patients transferred within the 6-12 months after introduction of the alarming system

interventions.name: standardized MT alarming system
interventions.description: Standardized alarming system via telephone loop in the primary thrombectomy centre triggered immediately after decision to mechanical thrombectomy in stroke patients admitted in primary stroke centers

primaryOutcomes.description: time from decision for MT (while patient still in the primary stroke center) to groin puncture (start of mechanical thrombectomy procedure in the primary thrombectomy center)

secondaryOutcomes.description: time from decision for MT to departure of the patient from primary stroke center (to the primary thrombectomy center)
time from decision for MT to arrival of the patient at the primary thrombectomy center
time from arrival of the patient at the primary thrombectomy center to groin puncture (start of mechanical thrombectomy procedure)

secondaryOutcomes.measure: rate of refusal of transfer requests due to lack of capacity
secondaryOutcomes.description: rate of patients that had to be transferred to a secondary thrombectomy center instead of the primary thrombectomy centre due to lack of capacity in the referral clinic
Time from decision for MT to request of emergency medical service for interhospital transfer
rate of periprocedural complications during MT
rate of successfully performed MT (mTICI \> 2b) of all patients with attempted MT
Time from groin puncture to successful recanalization
Adverse events within the first 7 days after transfer to referral center

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* age \>= 18 years
* diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke
* indication for mechanical thrombectomy
* admission to one of 7 participating primary stroke centers within in the catchment area of the referral center

Exclusion Criteria:

* unclear indication for mechanical thrombectomy (patients admitted for perfusion imaging before decision for or against a MT)
eligibilityModule.studyPopulation: Acute ischemic stroke patients admitted to one of 7 nonurban primary stroke centers with subsequent interhospital transfer to a referral center for mechanical thrombectomy in Southeast Bavaria, Germany.

ipdSharingStatementModule.description: No plan to make IPD available to other researchers.
